Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Matrices and their applications (some real world applications)
I gained a practical knowledge of Linear Algebra and how to use it in different applications.
matrix operations, decomposition, and some applications
We covered all of introductory linear algebra through eigen vectors and singular value decomposition.
Basics of linear algebra, such as Gaussian elimination, vector spaces, orthogonality, determinants, and eigenvalues
None - you can teach yourself all of this with MIT OpenCourseware and save yourself the headache. Don't take the class.
matrix computations and factorizations, four fundamental subspaces, orthogonality, intro to systems of differential equations, singular value decomposition
Linear algebra.
Basic Linear Algebra
I learned about the fundamentals of linear algebra.
Critical thinking skills and linear algebra tools
The foundations of matrix algebra and math proofs. Subspaces, linear transformations, various matrix decompositions, eigenvalues.

Strengths: Plenty of peer tutors, always someone available to see due to the structure of the class

Weaknesses: Not super heavy on real world applications, review sessions were very weak this past year

This is a good intro class. However, the difference in teaching is obvious between the different instructors. Also, a lot of the last two weeks of the class seemed like an amalgamation of various unconnected topics and they don't make sense in relation to each toher.

strengths - overall solid course for anyone who hasn't taken linear algebra yet. definitely a different way of thinking about math than calc and perhaps a little more applicable
weaknesses - overall the 3 sections didn't seem too unified in what topics they covered per week - our instructor didn't teach for one class and we were one class behind until the very end of the semester
"linear algebra with applications" seems deceiving. it should be called "linear algebra plus half a lecture about its applications". nothing against the instructors - the applications part was very interesting, but course should probably just be called linear algebra

I thought this course was poorly run logistically - there were no answer keys to homework and less feedback for students to improve their skills. Often times it felt like the homework didn't reflect examples in class, and students needed to go to external resources to teach themselves the material. The course lectures also felt like a direct regurgitation of Gilbert Strang's textbook.

Strengths: content was interesting, linear algebra is very powerful
Weaknesses: the instructor, lots of homework (even on exam/reading weeks)

No notes or reading were assigned. if you didn't go to class you wouldn't know what happened. we followed the book closely, which was what saved me. Besides the no notes nor readings assigned. No homework solutions were posted either. Never seen a similar class at Yale in a stem field.
There were very few strengths of the class - I guess the homework was fine, but the biggest weakness were the professors.

Strength: Goes straight to the point in lectures

Weakness: Poorly organized

not that many resources available on Canvas (no problem set solutions, which was especially difficult since problem sets weren't graded in time for the exams), few practice exams. The course was pretty fair though, in the sense that the exam questions weren't completely out of the blue

The material is taught in a logical progression, and the psets are challenging but doable.  I felt like by the end I had a relatively firm grasp on the subject and I feel like I learned genuinely useful knowledge. 
At least for our section, feedback was very hard to get. We weren't given back our midterms, so I have no idea what I got wrong, and psets were just marked with points - there were no comments about where we went wrong.

The only strength to this course was the peer tutors. The teacher did not show much interest in the class and it was structured pretty awfully. The classes were never engaging; when I looked around most people were on their phone. The hw would normally take two weeks to get back and the answers were never released with it so it was difficult to learn from the mistakes. Additionally, we never got back our tests and we only covered some minor applications of linear algebra within the last 30 minutes of the last day.
Content is interesting, could use more real life applications, needs more passionate staff
More example problems during class would be very helpful.
It needs to be more engaging and more passionately taught

Not enough online resources (practice problems, etc.). Section was pretty meh. Lecture was fine, but it was pretty much an information dump without much engagement. You will most likely be bored to death some classes (but paying attention in class is super important for the homework). A lot of material in this class you might have to teach yourself, so that is a downside. That being said, I never went to peer tutors -- and there seem to be a lot of peer tutor and instructor office hours -- so the resource upside is pretty good I guess.
I think that it wasn't completely explained conceptually, more aimed to just teach us what to do with the equation, rather than teach us to visualize the problems.
I'd recommend this only if you enjoy math

if you can handle math and if this can count towards your major, do it
if you are doing a stem-related field, you should consider this, especially if you are also doing heavy duty research that requires data analysis

Linear algebra is really important in future courses, so I would recommend this class from that perspective. The structure of the courses was really not facilitated to student learning, so be prepared to watch MIT Open Course lectures from Gilbert Strang to teach yourself the material.
Yes, it's very useful for pretty much any STEM field.
kinda. it is an easy class so you don't really need a teacher. I just taught myself from the book and the MIT opencourses.
Get as far away from this course as you can. If you really want to, take Math225 instead. It was a pretty bad learning experience.
The concepts learned were important, though the teaching could definitely be improved (if you had Sudesh for Math 120 you will be quite disappointed)
If you need to learn linear algebra, this course is fine. But if you don't, why are you here?
No, I would not unless it is absolutely necessary.
Its great as a slightly easier math course if your schedule is packed and dont want to delve into 225

The subject of linear algebra is really cool and useful (especially as a gateway for higher level QR classes). The homework is not always so crazy and the class is pretty straightforward with exams. Put in the time and you will do well. That being said, I don't know how 225 compares, but in a vacuum I would recommend 222 if you are a math or econ person.
